Award.AwardTitle: Global Proteome and Signal Pathway Phosphoproteome Dynamics during Appressorium Formation in the Rice Blast Fungus Magnaporthe oryzae

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant pathogenic fungi are responsible for major crop losses. To infect their hosts many fungi, including Magnaporthe oryzae, the causal agent of rice blast and the most destructive fungal disease of rice worldwide, have evolved to form a specialized infection cell, an appressorium. Appressorium formation is regulated by signal transduction pathways notably the cAMP and MAP kinase pathways, which results in activation of phosphorylation cascades leading to changes in gene expression, including genes involved in protein turnover. However, knowledge of these post-translational protein modifications and dynamic changes in proteins during appressorium formation is limited. The ability to conduct large scale analyses of proteins in living cells as well as measure changes in protein modifications has advanced dramatically in recent years. In this project, to further define and characterize the processes regulating appressorium formation, a comprehensive quantitative analysis of relative changes in protein abundance and phosphorylation patterns during appressorium formation will be conducted. The integration of gene expression and proteomics data will contribute substantially to constructing a more comprehensive view of the cellular processes underlying this fundamental biological process.

Broader Impacts: This project will have broad impact at several levels. The research will provide cross training in chemistry and fungal biology for the graduate student and post doctoral scholar involved in this project. An individualized mentoring program will be developed for the post doctoral scholar. The PI and co-PI will develop a new colloquium integrating general concepts in biology and chemistry around the premises of this project for high school students as well as provide research experience for undergraduates. Finally, through broad dissemination of the results from these studies, including an online open-source database, the knowledge will be invaluable for driving research to find practical solutions to rice blast and other diseases caused by fungal plant pathogens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungi have evolved to cause devastating diseases of plants and animals that frequently result in huge economic losses and human suffering.  For example, rice blast caused by Magnaporthe oryzae is the most destructive disease of rice worldwide. Few other plant pathogens, fungal or otherwise, have this impact on a global scale in terms of nutrition, livelihood, culture, and economic well-being. The infection of rice by M. oryzae is characterized by a fungal developmental sequence that begins after contact of an asexual spore with the leaf surface. Following germination of the spore, perception of physical and chemical cues by the fungus triggers development of a dome-shaped penetration structure known as the appressorium, which is tightly attached to the leaf surface. Appressoria generate tremendous internal turgor pressure, which facilitates mechanical penetration of the plant leaf surface. Following invasion of the leaf, the fungus maintains a non-symptomatic (biotrophic) relationship with the plant for a few days prior to entry into a necrotrophic phase characterized by the destruction of plant tissues, loss of rice and production of asexual spores leading to spread of the disease.

Pathogenic development of M. oryzae requires the recognition of external cues from the leaf surface followed by transmission of these signals to the nucleus in the fungus, triggering the morphogenetic sequence resulting in the production of an appressorium.  Critical to this process are multiple signaling pathways whereby certain proteins (kinases) phosphorylate other proteins setting up a phospho-relay. Phosphorylation of proteins alters their activities and consequently enables infection. In M. oryzae certain kinases are indispensible for pathogenicity and include the Pmk1 mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase, cyclic AMP dependent protein kinase A (PKA) and Pkc1-Mps1 MAP kinase pathways.  The overall goals of this project were to characterize global changes in proteins during appressorium formation as well as identity which proteins were specifically phosphorylated. We first set out to develop sophisticated analytical methods to quality as many proteins as possible in M. oryzae. We were able to identify and quantify the accumulation profiles of up to 5,000 proteins (representing over 40% of all possible proteins) using specialized work flows and sensitive mass spectrometers. This was a major accomplishment as we were dealing with very small biological samples.  In spores, we showed that most of the expressed proteins were associated with metabolism and energy, suggesting that spores are primed to germinate quickly when they land on a leaf surface. We discovered that during the formation of the appressorium, many proteins associated with cell wall biosynthesis, transport functions and production of extracellular proteins accumulated to high levels.  These proteins likely enable the dramatic changes in cell structure of the appressorium as well as the secretion of proteins to help attach the appressorium to the plant surface.  In addition, we identified several hundred proteins directly associated with CPKA. These are important proteins as they likely play a direct role in fungal infection. Following these studies, we developed microscale procedures to examine changes in protein phosphorylation during appressorium formation and were able to characterize nearly 3000 phosphosites on more than 1500 proteins. Nearly 450 phosphosites showed dramatic changes during appressorium formation, with over 250 being specifically regulated by CPKA. Many of these proteins play a central role in protein turnover (autophagy) and cellular morphology (actin). These represent important findings as the fungus recycles its cellular contents to form the appressorium and penetrate the rice leaf. Several key regulatory proteins including transcription factors were phosphorylated during appressorium formation. We showed that at least one of these proteins is crucial for regulating metabolic processes central to appressorium function.  Finally, using data from previous gene expression studies and data generated in this project we were able to create a comprehensive model of appressorium development and function.

In addition to advancing basic knowledge and understanding, the accomplishments of the project have broader impacts for society. Crop losses due to disease are a major constraint to produce sufficient food for an ever-expanding global population. A deeper understanding of how pathogens cause disease, particularly those that threaten a major crop such as rice, will enable development of more durable and environmentally friendly strategies to control disease. Methods (both chemical and genetic) that interfere with the specific proteins and their phosphorylation during the infection process will stop disease. At the research level, this collaborative project also introduced students and senior scientists (including chemists with expertize in mass spectrometry) to opportunities to work on problems new to them that directly benefit society.
